articles.headline: Koch Executive’s Harassment in China Adds to Fears Among Visitors
articles.snippet: Amid worsening trade tensions, an American businessman was barred from leaving for days, in an apparent message to President Trump. Others worry they may be next.
articles.abstract: Amid worsening trade tensions, an American businessman was barred from leaving for days, in an apparent message to President Trump. Others worry they may be next.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Koch Industries executive was told he could not leave China. An ex-diplomat who helped organize a technology forum in Beijing was hassled by authorities who wanted to question him. An industry group developed contingency plans, in case its offices were raided and computer servers were seized.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur, Alexandra Stevenson and Edward Wong

articles.headline: Jeffrey Epstein Registered as a Sex Offender in 2 States. In New Mexico, He Didn’t Have To.
articles.snippet: The New York financier’s case points to the patchwork of laws around the country that govern the registration of sex offenders.
articles.abstract: The New York financier’s case points to the patchwork of laws around the country that govern the registration of sex offenders.
articles.lead_paragraph: STANLEY, N.M. — Jeffrey Epstein, the New York financier, managed to evade federal prosecution a decade ago in a Florida sex case involving dozens of teenage girls, in part by agreeing to register as a sex offender. But for a man with many residences, and many high-powered lawyers, registering as a sex offender was not the blanket penalty it might seem.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero and Nicholas Kulish

articles.headline: As Nations Look to Tax Tech Firms, U.S. Scrambles to Broker a Deal
articles.snippet: The proposed levies on firms like Facebook and Google are pitting traditional allies against one another and threatening to set off a cascade of tax increases and tariffs.
articles.abstract: The proposed levies on firms like Facebook and Google are pitting traditional allies against one another and threatening to set off a cascade of tax increases and tariffs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For most of the 21st century, wealthy nations have engaged in a race to the bottom on corporate taxes, cutting rates in an effort to poach business activity across borders. Very quickly, that script has flipped.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Turkey Gets Shipment of Russian Missile System, Defying U.S.
articles.snippet: The purchase of the sophisticated S-400 antiaircraft equipment was fiercely opposed by NATO and by Washington, which is expected to respond with sanctions.
articles.abstract: The purchase of the sophisticated S-400 antiaircraft equipment was fiercely opposed by NATO and by Washington, which is expected to respond with sanctions.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Defying strenuous American objections and the threat of sanctions, Turkey began receiving the first shipment of a sophisticated Russian surface-to-air missile system on Friday, a step certain to test the country’s uneasy place in the NATO alliance.

articles.headline: Why Sanders Wanted His Meeting With a Rabbi Kept Secret
articles.snippet: Bernie Sanders’s advisers and allies want him to get personal with voters as he struggles in the 2020 race. But that isn’t his style.
articles.abstract: Bernie Sanders’s advisers and allies want him to get personal with voters as he struggles in the 2020 race. But that isn’t his style.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — [Read more: Bernie Sanders drops out of 2020 democratic presidential race.]
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: The 2008 Crash Made This Madrid Suburb a Ghost Town. Now It’s Coming Alive.
articles.snippet: Valdeluz, created as a commuter haven, is emerging from a lost decade after the financial crisis. But its former dreams, like a 1,500-student school, remain out of reach.
articles.abstract: Valdeluz, created as a commuter haven, is emerging from a lost decade after the financial crisis. But its former dreams, like a 1,500-student school, remain out of reach.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Valdeluz, a town outside Madrid that was envisioned as a commuter’s paradise when it was created 15 years ago, there was always supposed to be a school. And a private one, for kindergartners to high schoolers, opened in September 2007 — just a year before the global financial crisis burst Spain’s property bubble.
articles.byline: By Raphael Minder and Alexander Ingram

articles.headline: Ford and VW Agree to Share Costs of Self-Driving and Electric Cars
articles.snippet: A deal announced Friday is an example of how carmakers are joining forces to survive a major shift in technology. But can two longtime rivals cooperate?
articles.abstract: A deal announced Friday is an example of how carmakers are joining forces to survive a major shift in technology. But can two longtime rivals cooperate?
articles.lead_paragraph: Ford Motor and Volkswagen said Friday that they would team up to develop self-driving cars and share electric-car components. The move broadens an existing alliance and shows how automakers are putting aside rivalries to manage the cost of new technologies.
articles.byline: By Neal E. Boudette and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Acosta to Resign as Labor Secretary Over Jeffrey Epstein Plea Deal
articles.snippet: President Trump said the decision to resign was made by his labor secretary, R. Alexander Acosta.
articles.abstract: President Trump said the decision to resign was made by his labor secretary, R. Alexander Acosta.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s embattled labor secretary, R. Alexander Acosta, announced his resignation on Friday amid continuing questions about his handling of a sex crimes case involving the financier Jeffrey Epstein when Mr. Acosta was a federal prosecutor in Florida.
articles.byline: By Annie Karni, Eileen Sullivan and Noam Scheiber
